qas.question: On 6 June 2005, The Times redesigned what page of its newspaper?
In 2005, The Times dropped the practice of printing what kind of feature of its correspondents?
Which author and solicitor has had more letters published on the main letters page of The Times than any other known contributor?

answers.text: David Green of Castle Morris Pembrokeshire

qas.question: The leading author and solicitor of the letters page in The Times had how many articles published?
What is the name of the leading article that referenced the removal of a major feature in The Times in 2005?

context: On 6 June 2005, The Times redesigned its <a0_0>Letters page<a0_0/>, dropping the practice of printing correspondents' <a1_0>full postal addresses<a1_0/>. Published letters were long regarded as one of the paper's key constituents. Author/solicitor <a2_0>David Green of Castle Morris Pembrokeshire<a2_0/> has had more letters published on the main letters page than any other known contributor – <a3_0>158<a3_0/> by 31 January 2008. According to its leading article, "<a4_0>From Our Own Correspondents<a4_0/>", removal of full postal addresses was in order to fit more letters onto the page.
